news.title: 'Taylor Swift Is A Nazi' Narrative Boosted By Coordinated Online Effort, New Report Finds
news.text:
Online talk around Taylor Swift‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Life of a Showgirl‚Äù album in October was disrupted by a coordinated, ‚Äúnarrative manipulation‚Äù effort that accused the singer of promoting Nazism and MAGA ideology, according to a new report from the behavioral intelligence startup GUDEA.

The report flagged narratives pushed by inauthentic accounts across a number of platforms, including one claiming that ‚ÄúTaylor Swift is a Nazi,‚Äù an accusation that served as a ‚Äúcatalyst for a secondary, authentic conversation‚Äù comparing Swift to self-described Nazi and Hitler-loving rapper Ye (formerly Kanye West).

Users who weren‚Äôt engaging with conspiracy theories ‚Äúnevertheless entered the conversation in response to the fallout created by inauthentic users‚Äù to defend the singer and to slam the ‚Äúirrationality‚Äù of such a narrative, the report found.

‚ÄúThe pattern of inauthentic provocation [to] authentic user discourse is a hallmark of successful narrative manipulation,‚Äù GUDEA‚Äôs report reads.

‚ÄúIt demonstrates how small bursts of coordinated activity can reshape cultural perception by forcing mainstream audiences to respond to extremized framing.‚Äù

The report comes months after wild interpretations of Swift‚Äôs lyrics and imagery bubbled up online, including posts that connected a lightning-bolt-like necklace in her merch store to a Nazi SS symbol. 

GUDEA also found a ‚Äúsignificant user overlap between accounts pushing the Swift ‚ÄòNazi‚Äô narrative‚Äù and those part of a ‚Äúseparate astroturf campaign‚Äù attacking Blake Lively, a friend of Swift who is involved in a sexual harassment lawsuit against her ‚ÄúIt Ends With Us‚Äù co-star and director Justin Baldoni.

Following Swift‚Äôs album release, she was accused of making racist swipes at her fianc√© Travis Kelce‚Äôs ex-girlfriend after using the word ‚Äúsavage‚Äù on her song ‚ÄúEldest Daughter.‚Äù

Some posts tried depicting her as a ‚Äútrad wife‚Äù to Kelce and claimed she promoted white supremacy with the lyrics ‚Äúgot the whole block looking like you‚Äù on her song ‚ÄúWi$h Li$t,‚Äù despite the line appearing to make a nod to her desire to start a family with her NFL star fianc√©.

Others accused her of embracing far-right ideology, despite her history of backing Democratic candidates ‚Äî such as former Vice President Kamala Harris ‚Äî over the years.

Georgia Paul, GUDEA‚Äôs head of customer success, speculated to Rolling Stone magazine that the narrative-pushing efforts could serve as a test run for ‚Äúnefarious actors‚Äù outside of the U.S.

‚Äú[They may] have reasons to see, ‚ÄòIf I can move the fan base for Taylor Swift ‚Äî an icon who is this political figure, in a way ‚Äî does that mean I can do it in other places?‚Äô‚Äù Paul said.
news.author: Ben Blanchet

news.title: The NetflixWBD Sale Means Fewer Seats for Black Creatives and Culture
news.text:
Netflix intends to purchase Warner Bros. for $72 billion. The deal would give the world‚Äôs largest streamer ownership of a 102-year-old archive including Hollywood‚Äôs most legendary film and television IP‚Äîfrom Casablanca to The Color Purple. The monumental sale arrives at a time of extreme economic headwinds and unprecedented job losses in the entertainment industry.

This isn‚Äôt just a historic transaction. It powers a broader global trend toward massive consolidation in media. 

But beneath the headlines is a more urgent question: What does the world‚Äôs most powerful streamer combined with the most storied studio mean for Black creatives, Black culture, and Black economic power inside Hollywood?

Here‚Äôs my forecast.

1. A shrinking seat at the table

Clearing redundancies and restructuring are inevitable in acquisitions at this scale, and shareholders mandate it to reduce costs. Unfortunately, Black senior leaders and Black middle managers often bear the brunt of cuts. Warner Bros. Discovery only has a handful of Black senior leaders, including Channing Dungey, Warner‚Äôs Chairman and CEO of their television group, and a longtime entertainment leader who previously ran ABC Entertainment. Under Netflix rule, a company with a vastly different operating structure, does Dungey‚Äôs role and influence survive?

And what of Black employees in the middle layers of the company, who are already significantly outnumbered? Consolidation typically leads to fewer Black decision makers in the room, fewer champions for diverse storytelling, and waning influence during a period already defined by anti-DEI backlash.

2. Conglomerates trigger steely gatekeeping

Sinners delivered a culture-shifting win for Warner Bros, defying the decline of theatrical releases, with a global box office nearing $400 million. But the scale of Warner‚Äôs $90 million investment on the Coogler‚ÄìJordan partnership is an anomaly. For the average Black filmmaker, passing through Hollywood‚Äôs steely gatekeepers remains extraordinarily difficult. Even when projects clear that bar, many face early cancellations or one-season fates.

In summer 2021, HBO infamously cancelled Misha Green‚Äôs Lovecraft Country after a single acclaimed season and has offered very few Black-led series since. But it‚Äôs also important to acknowledge historical context. Consolidation does not automatically mean fewer opportunities for Black film and TV.

In the era when Time Warner operated as one of the world‚Äôs most powerful entertainment conglomerates, it housed Warner Bros., Warner Music Group, Time Inc., including People, Entertainment Weekly, Essence, and the book publisher Simon & Schuster.

During that period, Warner fueled the heyday of Black cinema in the 1990s with titles like Set It Off, Friday, and Hoodlum, and powered the rise of Black sitcoms, among them include classics Family Matters and The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.

But that same conglomerate also produced the nadir of Black cinema and the dearth of the Black sitcom, often justified under the biased theory Black-led stories are ‚Äútoo niche‚Äù or lacked broad cultural appeal.

Consolidation creates possibility and danger. Historically, offering Black storytellers a platform and later, snatching it away.

3. Data-driven decision-making overrules creative risk

Netflix is fundamentally a technology company. Its ethos prioritizes data, optimization, and agility. This is smart business but often overshadows creative risk-taking, which is the spinal cord to cultural progress.

Under a Netflix-led Warner Bros., would Sinners have been greenlit at that scale? Would Coogler have secured such a rare, creator-favorable deal structure?

Data-driven forecasting is often used to reinforce the disproven myth that Black film and TV don‚Äôt perform. When data intelligence overrules cultural intelligence, Black storytelling becomes vulnerable to algorithmic erasure.

To Netflix‚Äôs credit, the streamer backed series like Mara Brock-Akil‚Äôs Forever and Survival of the Thickest starring Michelle Buteau and Tasha Smith. But inheriting Warner‚Äôs creative engine means the bar must be set higher. Way high up. Not merely maintained.

4. Deepened dependency on Black dollars and cultural power, with little investment

A Netflix‚ÄìWarner Bros. combination creates the single most powerful entertainment company in the world. But no entertainment company generates meaningful profits without Black consumers, who historically over-index on time spent on entertainment, and whose cultural leadership and taste drive innovation across the industry.

Netflix leans heavily into ‚ÄúStrong Black Lead‚Äù, a social-first marketing vertical launched early 2018 to increase Black subscribers. The streamer‚Äôs leadership, including co-CEO Ted Sarandos, publicly supported former Vice President Kamala Harris‚Äôs presidential run. But there remains a wide gap between messaging and the company‚Äôs investment in Black senior leaders, Black producers, and Black original programming.

A merger at this scale could also trigger subscription cost increases, disproportionately impacting communities already facing inflation in housing, food, and digital access. Black influence fuels the entertainment business. Yet Black creatives rarely receive equitable investment in return.

The Road Ahead: antitrust, power, and the stakes for Black culture

Although the sale is agreed upon, it still requires regulatory approval. The Department of Justice and the FCC will evaluate antitrust implications‚Äîconcerns that often lead to required divestitures, spin-offs, ownership caps, or mandates around content distribution.

Following Netflix‚Äôs deal announcement, Paramount, in a last ditch effort, launched an even more aggressive bid to secure Warner Bros, including its television networks, valued at $108.4 billion. David Ellison‚Äôs SkyDance company acquired Paramount for $8 billion summer 2025 with support from father Larry Ellison, co-founder of software company Oracle. Skydance has since laid off over 1,000 Paramount employees. Both father and son have shown political alignment with President Trump behind-the-scenes. Reportedly, Trump is more enthusiastic about Ellison‚Äôs bid for Warner, signaling the president would push for speedy FCC approval. 

Though the Ellisons‚Äôs offer for Warner far exceeds Netflix by some $36 billion, Sarandos remains confident its deal will close.

Even if Netflix wins FCC approval to merge Warner into their streaming operations, in a Trump nation begetting anti-DEI actions, chances regulators prioritize protections for Black creatives are slim. What does it say about Hollywood and America if the most consequential entertainment merger of our time leads to measurable decline in Black influence and Black creative access? Hollywood sits on the backbone of Black talent and storytelling. This moment will pressure-cook a time of mercurial change and will test if the industry intends to honor this truth or consolidate past it.
news.summary: The NetflixWBD Sale Means Fewer Seats for Black Creatives and Culture
news.author: Geneva S. Thomas

news.title: Miami gives Dems hopes for Florida midterm magic. But hurdles loom large
news.text:
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre putting in the work,‚Äù Fried said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre getting great candidates, and now it‚Äôs time for us to continue building this momentum into 2026.‚Äù

But Democrats still have to contend with some serious headwinds in Florida. They‚Äôre heading into the midterms with a 1.4 million-voter registration disadvantage against Republicans. And the GOP in Florida has massively more cash than Democrats, raising $12.7 million during the first three quarters of this year compared to Democrats‚Äô $1.5 million ‚Äî not to mention severe morale and infighting issues that plagued the state party.

‚ÄúThis was a small win for Democrats ‚Ä¶ but they‚Äôve turned this into big national news to keep their donors happy,‚Äù said Angie Wong, a Republican executive committee member in Miami.

Miami, unlike most of Florida, has a 23,000-person voter registration advantage in favor of Democrats when counting both active and inactive voters. While Trump won Miami-Dade County by 11 points in 2024, he lost the city to former Vice President Kamala Harris by 1 point. Its outgoing GOP mayor, Francis Suarez, started out his years in office shunning policies from Trump and DeSantis ‚Äî though he‚Äôs come around since. Despite losing Miami, Republicans won a special election for the state Senate on Tuesday night and maintained a majority on the Miami city commission.

‚ÄúRepublicans are gaining strength, and trajectory on voter registration is not slowing,‚Äù said Evan Power, chair of the Republican Party of Florida. ‚ÄúThe fact is, Democrats making a lot of noise about a Kamala City shows how little movement they have. The Democrat Party is still on the verge of extinction in Florida.‚Äù

Florida Democrats also faced cratering morale and infighting earlier this year, with the state Senate Democratic leader leaving the party and two state House members flipping to the GOP after the 2024 election. One Miami-based Democratic political organizer, who was granted anonymity to relay a candid assessment, said there was still 11 months until the next election with ‚Äúinfinite opportunities for leadership‚Äù to mess it up, including if they choose to ‚Äúmeddle in primaries‚Äù or ‚Äúget bogged down in the whole progressive vs. establishment‚Äù fight.

Still, the Miami race gave Democrats a jolt of excitement as it became more nationalized, coming a week after the party overperformed in a House special election in Tennessee. The Democratic National Committee sent volunteers to help, and major Democrats ‚Äî including rumored 2028 candidates for president ‚Äî popped into the Magic City or endorsed Higgins over social media as her prospects for victory improved.
news.author: Kimberly Leonard

news.title: Kamala Harris quells new speculation about CA governor run in 2026
news.text:
Kamala Harris‚Äô team is shooting down speculation that the former vice president is again considering a run for California governor next year, after she announced in July that she would not.

Fueled by polls showing a weak Democratic field of gubernatorial candidates, political circles were abuzz this week that Harris, the former Democratic presidential nominee, was having second thoughts.

Two sources close to Harris who were unauthorized to speak publicly confirmed Wednesday that she plans to stay out of the race.

After her 2024 loss to President Donald Trump, Harris initially considered running in California‚Äôs open governor‚Äôs race next year but in July announced that her future public service ‚Äúwill not be in elected office.‚Äù On Wednesday, an aide pointed to that announcement when asked if Harris was reconsidering.

Harris recently told the New York Times that she planned to ‚Äúramp up‚Äù her political engagement in 2026, forming a political action committee and paying the Democratic National Committee $7 million for her email list.

She has spent the last two months on a book tour for ‚Äú107 Days,‚Äù her memoir about her truncated presidential campaign, and on Wednesday announced added more than a dozen new stops in early 2026.

Rumors flew around political circles in recent days that Harris was reconsidering her decision to stay out of the California race, citing the lack of a gubernatorial frontrunner. With six months to go until the primary election, recent polls have shown nearly a third of California voters are undecided about whom to support in the governor‚Äôs race.

Attorney General Rob Bonta is also believed to be considering a run for governor after initially saying in February that he would focus on his current position ‚Äî a claim he reiterated last week to reporters. His adviser, Dan Newman, did not respond to requests for comment Wednesday.

An Emerson college poll conducted in early December showed two Republican candidates leading the state‚Äôs gubernatorial field, with Democrats Eric Swalwell and Katie Porter close behind.

After losing the 2024 election, Harris initially regrouped in Los Angeles out of the public eye.

In her memoir and in interviews, she has swiped at Newsom, former Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg, and Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro, who she considered as a running mate before deciding on Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz.

She wrote that Newsom initially declined her calls after former president Joe Biden dropped out and endorsed her because he was on the treadmill, and later on a hike.

Later that night, Newsom endorsed Harris. The two came up together in San Francisco politics in the 1990s and share political and fundraising strategists.

This story was originally published December 10, 2025 at 2:08 PM.
news.author: Lia Russell,Nicole Nixon

news.title: ‚ÄòThousands of people are coming to hear my voice‚Äô: Kamala Harris declares herself to be a ‚Äòhistoric figure‚Äô
news.text:
Kamala Harris, Joe Biden‚Äôs vice president who was appointed ‚Äúborder czar‚Äù during his time in the Oval office and allowed one of the biggest national catastrophes ever through millions and millions of illegal aliens, including terrorists, breaking into the country, now considers herself a ‚Äúhistoric figure.‚Äù

A report from Fox News noted that she also boasted about having a marble bust of herself carved to be placed in Congress.

She was being interviewed by the New York Times in a promotion for a coming book she is selling and told reporters at the newspaper ‚Äúshe no longer feels ‚Äòburdened‚Äô by the need to achieve a place in history.‚Äù

Besides her border failure, she also confirmed she was heart and soul aligned with Joe Biden‚Äôs agenda promoting abortion for all ‚Äì at taxpayer expense ‚Äì and transgenderism, including body mutilating surgeries for children.

She admitted all that when she said she couldn‚Äôt think of anything done during Biden‚Äôs term that she would have done differently.

Further, when she was the Democrat nominee for president in 2024, she failed in dramatic style, ceding every swing state, the Electoral College and the popular vote to President Trump.

‚ÄúI understand the focus on ‚Äô28 and all that,‚Äù Harris complained. ‚ÄòBut there will be a marble bust of me in Congress. I am a historic figure like any Vice President of the United States ever was. Thousands of people are coming to hear my voice. Thousands and thousands.‚Äù

She said the tour promoting her book, for which sales are dismal, constantly is ‚Äúsold out.‚Äù

A commentary at BizPacReview bluntly asked, ‚ÄúIs she drunk?‚Äù

It explained, ‚ÄúA New York Times profile on the woman who could have been President of the United States indicates that voters haven‚Äôt seen the last of her, but the less-than-flattering nature of the piece is enough to make one wonder if she‚Äôll ever receive enough support to make another run for the Oval Office.‚Äù

The Times wrote, ‚ÄúOld advisers, both allied and estranged, have squinted from afar at her book tour, wondering what exactly her strategy is, or if there is any at all. She has done little to distance herself from former President Joseph R. Biden Jr. besides admitting aloud that it was ‚Äòrecklessness‚Äô on her part not to have discouraged him from running again. There has been virtually none of the strategic repackaging that a future candidate typically does, the buffing out of flaws and shining up of strengths.‚Äù

The report pointed out voters ‚Äúhad no idea‚Äù for what she stood in 2024.

Reports also reveal she is using her book to ‚Äúsettle scores‚Äù with people, including Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro to Joe Biden who are criticized.

Her book also includes complaints about how hard it was to get anything positive said about her work.

The Times report said she swears freely, letting fly a two-word phrase ‚Äúrhyming with ‚Äòbucket'‚Äù and mostly has been a bystander as the Democrat party struggles to find an identity following its collapse in 2024.

She‚Äôs slipped lately in polling assessing Democrats aiming for a 2028 primary and praises Democrats in Congress for shutting down government for many weeks, hurting people in the process, unsuccessfully trying to get Republicans to raid taxpayers for hundreds of billions of dollars to give to illegal aliens.
news.summary: Boasts of having marble bust of her placed in Congress
news.author: Bob Unruh

news.title: WTF? Embracing profanity is one thing both political parties seem to agree on
news.text:
Vice President JD Vance called a podcast host a ‚Äúdips-t‚Äù in September. In Thanksgiving remarks before troops, Vance joked that anyone who said they liked turkey was ‚Äúfull of s‚Äì.‚Äù After one National Guard member was killed in a shooting in Washington last month and a second was critically injured, top Trump aide Steven Cheung told a reporter on social media to ‚Äúshut the f‚Äì up‚Äù when she wrote that the deployment of troops in the nation‚Äôs capital was ‚Äúfor political show.‚Äù

Among Democrats, former Vice President Kamala Harris earned a roar of approval from her audience in September when she condemned the Trump administration by saying ‚Äúthese mother‚Äî- are crazy.‚Äù After Trump called for the execution of several Democratic members of Congress last month, Sen. Chris Murphy, D-Conn., said it was time for people with influence to ‚Äúpick a f‚Äî side.‚Äù Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer of New York said the administration cannot ‚Äúf‚Äì around‚Äù with the release of the Jeffrey Epstein files. Democratic Rep. Jasmine Crockett, who on Monday announced her Senate campaign in Texas, did not hold back earlier this year when asked what she would tell Elon Musk if given the chance: ‚ÄúF‚Äì off.‚Äù

The volley of vulgarities underscore an ever-coarsening political environment that often plays out on social media or other digital platforms where the posts or video clips that evoke the strongest emotions are rewarded with the most engagement.

‚ÄúIf you want to be angry at someone, be angry at the social media companies,‚Äù Utah Gov. Spencer Cox, a Republican, said Tuesday night at Washington National Cathedral, where he spoke at an event focused on political civility. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not a fair fight. They‚Äôve hijacked our brains. They understand these dopamine hits. Outrage sells.‚Äù

Cox, whose national profile rose after calling for civility in the wake of conservative activist Charlie Kirk‚Äôs assassination in his state, approved an overhaul of social media laws meant to protect children. A federal judge has temporarily blocked the state law.
news.author: Steven Sloan

news.title: Miami election was a ‚Äòshot in the arm‚Äô for Dems but careful calling it a comeback | Opinion
news.text:
The analysis and punditry of the results of Miami‚Äôs Tuesday night election started even before Eileen Higgins, a Democrat, won the mayoral race.

There‚Äôs no doubt this was a good ‚Äî even great ‚Äî night for Democrats. The nonpartisan race turned into a red-versus-blue contest with President Donald Trump‚Äôs endorsement of Emilio Gonzalez, a Republican, and the infusion of resources Higgins got from national Democrats. But does this mean Florida ‚Äî and Miami-Dade County, which Trump easily carried in 2024 ‚Äî are back in play for the Democratic Party?

Without doubt, Higgins made history as the first woman to lead Miami and the first elected mayor to run as a Democrat since the 1990s. But we should be careful with extrapolations, especially when turnout in city elections are embarrassingly low: fewer than 38,000 Miamians voted Tuesday ‚Äî out of 176,000 registered voters.

We wish this election had remained nonpartisan. But in today‚Äôs politically polarized climate, it was only a matter of time before local races‚Äî where issues such as affordability, infrastructure and public transportation shouldn‚Äôt be partisan ‚Äî became embroiled in party politics.

Alas, that ship has sailed.

The mayoral race became a test for two things: whether Democrats can crawl their way out of the electoral hole they dug for themselves in South Florida, and whether a Trump endorsement sinks or elevates candidates in a general election.

Gonzalez lost by nearly 20 points. The fact that Trump‚Äôs support did not get him elected is no surprise. The president‚Äôs endorsement may work in a GOP primary but a general election in a city that Kamala Harris carried, albeit by a slim margin, in 2024 is a different story. Trump‚Äôs support also failed to get several candidates elected in important U.S. Senate and gubernatorial races across the country in 2022. Trump has also lost support among Hispanic voters, a key demographic in Miami.

In hindsight, would Gonzalez have been better off running only on his r√©sum√© as a former city manager and retired Army colonel who reversed in court the city commission‚Äôs decision to move the 2025 elections to next year without voter approval? Even that might not have been enough to close the gap on Higgins‚Äô advantage.

The Tuesday election was a ‚Äúshot in the arm‚Äù for Democrats, Fernand Amandi, a Miami Democratic pollster, told the Herald Editorial Board.

‚ÄúI think, for the first time, they have something they can start to build on,‚Äù he said.

Higgins‚Äô win will encourage Democratic donors to take a second look at Florida, a state the party has essentially written off in recent elections, and it‚Äôs an indicator they should not ignore the state anymore, Amandi said. But even the most optimistic Democrats are probably not saying this suddenly means Florida is back in play for them. The 2026 elections will still be a challenge for the party that has been hemorrhaging voters and has ceded control to the GOP, including in former blue bastions like South Florida.

Now that Higgins has won two competitive races ‚Äî for mayor and Miami-Dade County commissioner in 2018 ‚Äî consultants will inevitably begin looking at her next political move (she gave up her county seat less than halfway through her second term to run for mayor). But Higgins must focus on implementing an ambitious agenda that includes streamlining the city‚Äôs slow permitting system, building more affordable housing and improving public transit.

Above all, Higgins‚Äô legacy will be defined by whether she can change the image of Miami from a city hall where scandals and bad behavior are the status quo. She will have to accomplish all of that with the limited powers Miami‚Äôs charter gives her position. Unlike the mayors of Miami-Dade County and other cities, she will not have administrative powers, which are delegated to a city manager she can appoint. Higgins, however, should be strategic with her existing powers to veto legislation and whip votes on the commission on issues she cares about.

Miami‚Äôs mayoral election was a good night for the Democratic Party, but the real measure of success will be if the next four years are better for the residents of the city.
news.author: The Miami Herald Editorial Board

news.title: Kamala Harris to visit Madison book tour about failed presidential bid
news.text:
MADISON - Kamala Harris will bring her book tour to Madison next year, promoting her account of the whirlwind 2024 presidential election and her loss to Donald Trump.

Harris will appear at the Orpheum Theater in downtown Madison at 1 p.m. on Sunday, March 1.

The event is being held in partnership with local bookstore A Room of One's Own. 

The visit is one of 18 appearances Harris will make across the U.S. this spring, following her 17-stop fall 2025 tour. 

The former Democratic nominee for president stepped into the race after Joe Biden dropped out, after facing pressure and scrutiny regarding his age and mental faculties.

But her run, limited to 107 days, was not without controversy, which is detailed in her book, aptly named "107 Days."

Harris shares details about her relationship with Biden, her regrets regarding the campaign and goes as far as to criticize her running mate, Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz, according to USA Today.

She also aims at Trump and Vice President JD Vance, criticizing everything from their stance on immigration to military service.

The last time Harris visited Madison ‚Äî where she lived from the ages of 3 to 5 ‚Äî was Oct. 30, 2024, during a star-studded rally featuring live performances from Mumford & Sons and Gracie Abrams.

Tickets for the March 1 event go on sale Friday, Dec. 11, and can be purchased through the Orpheum's website. Tickets for a meet-and-greet before the event can also be purchased.

Laura Schulte can be reached at leschulte@jrn.com and on X @SchulteLaura.
news.author: Journal Sentinel

news.title: Automation and Intimacy Brought Video Podcasters Out of the Man Cave
news.text:
In the course of 2025, the video-podcast clip in general became a major unit of discourse. Once upon a time, aspiring public intellectuals and digital-native commentators had blogs. Then they had Twitter accounts, snarking from behind cartoon avatars; then podcasts, speaking into microphones into the void; then newsletters, publishing reams of text into our inboxes. In all of those formats, the human body was conspicuously absent‚Äîbut no longer. With the rise of the somewhat oxymoronic video podcast, the de-rigueur medium is a digital talk show of one, an eponymous production performed‚Äîface, body, outfit, and soul‚Äîfor the camera. We don‚Äôt just listen to Friedland, Ezra Klein, ‚ÄúCall Her Daddy‚Äù ‚Äôs Alex Cooper, ‚ÄúTalk Easy‚Äù ‚Äôs Sam Fragoso, ‚ÄúThrowing Fits‚Äù ‚Äôs James Harris and Lawrence Schlossman, or myriad other podcast proprietors anymore; we watch, often in closeup, every expression that flits across their faces, and thus cultivate a kind of parasocial intimacy usually reserved for Hollywood actors. There is no more hiding behind a byline; the moment mandates hair stylists and makeup. And, with the end of faceless punditry, measured neutrality moves toward obsolescence, too. The quality that hosts need in order to court and maintain audiences online is a dose of charismatic feeling, preferably caught in thirty seconds or less.
A few early adopters have been broadcasting their podcasts on video for many years. Joe Rogan has been filming his podcast since it launched in 2009, and the tech tastemaker Lex Fridman started filming his conversations back in 2018. But the mass rush toward video podcasting began with the 2024 Presidential race, which made clear just how much influence on public opinion shows like Rogan‚Äôs exerted. Donald Trump, J. D. Vance, and Elon Musk all took their turns doing three-hour gab sessions with Rogan in the run-up to Election Day; that August, Trump went viral discussing addiction in an unusually touchy-feely moment on Theo Von‚Äôs video podcast. MAGA‚Äôs success reaching voters this way‚Äîand Kamala Harris‚Äôs regrettable decision not to go on Rogan‚Äîsparked a realization that the medium was more than passive man-cave listening. Early this year, YouTube revealed that a billion monthly users consumed podcasts on its platform and declared itself ‚Äúthe most frequently used service for listening to podcasts in the U.S.‚Äù
During Trump‚Äôs first year back in office, D.I.Y. footage of two people talking into microphones has shaped the news cycle as much as any cable network. In January, the Times columnist Ross Douthat patched Steve Bannon in over Zoom for a conversation first aired on an episode of the Times‚Äô ‚ÄúMatter of Opinion‚Äù podcast and then syndicated on Douthat‚Äôs new video podcast, ‚ÄúInteresting Times.‚Äù In a surreal mise en sc√®ne, Douthat, appearing in high res in a cozy studio, watched Bannon‚Äôs face on a laptop as he denounced ‚ÄúBroligarchs‚Äù such as Musk, whose DOGE operations were ramping up at the time, signalling the first clear schism between the MAGA right and the tech overlords who backed Trump in 2024. (Watching someone watch a Zoom call is a video-podcast innovation of dubious appeal.) Then, in February, Musk made a redux appearance on Rogan‚Äôs show and delivered one of his most in-depth public discussions of DOGE; on YouTube, the episode racked up more than fourteen million views. The video podcast was suddenly a news-making venue, a makeshift press conference at a time when, thanks in part to Trump‚Äôs draconian approach to the First Amendment, press was more limited than ever.
What‚Äôs motivating the turn to video goes beyond the strategic utility of cultivating intimacy with an audience; the trend has equally to do with the structural mechanics of disseminating content online. Even as podcasts exploded in popularity during the early twenty-tens, the form had problems with discovery and distribution. Isolated bits of audio were not likely to go viral, because there was no centralized social-media-style feed for audio content, and because the major podcasting apps did not use algorithmic recommendations to help creators find fresh audiences. If you are an audio podcaster looking for listeners, you have to rely on word of mouth or pop up on other productions hoping to grab some of their fans. But, if you piggyback your audio release on video channels, you can reach new audiences through the automated feeds of YouTube, TikTok, and X. Gavin Newsom, the governor of California, apparently hoped to benefit accordingly when he d√©buted a video podcast, ‚ÄúThis Is Gavin Newsom,‚Äù in March, that seemed intended to plant him in the public psyche as a 2028 Presidential contender. (By the next election, perhaps YouTube-channel-subscriber numbers will be as meaningful as a candidate‚Äôs performance in the polls.) The same month, Amy Poehler, an actor, writer, and comedy power-producer who ostensibly has little need for a new platform, launched her own video podcast, ‚ÄúGood Hang,‚Äù fostering a direct audience outside the usual Hollywood channels. There‚Äôs a certain levelling effect at play: no matter how big your name is, the ideal media strategy today seems to be a stage set and a microphone. In August, Taylor Swift used ‚ÄúNew Heights,‚Äù the video podcast co-hosted by her now fianc√© Travis Kelce, to divulge details of her latest album. Watching fans pore over the footage for clues in the couple‚Äôs body language, one couldn‚Äôt help but think that audio doesn‚Äôt stand a chance.
The video podcast has established a new aesthetic of information‚Äîor perhaps just revived one that was more familiar in the era of ‚ÄúCrossfire‚Äù debates on CNN. We watch for signs of emotional gravitas as much as for the content of what is being said. Authority adheres to hosts through their acts of sheer duration, with some broadcasting several times a week or for hours every day. Through video, we get to know our pundits the same way we engage with influencers, and the more we are convinced by their multimedia performances the more readily we join their podcasting personality cults. Increasingly, this world of digital broadcasting is embroiled in slow-burning rivalries and rhetorical fights, a Marvel universe of independent opinion-givers. In September, the writer Ta-Nehisi Coates appeared on Ezra Klein‚Äôs hit Times podcast, ‚ÄúThe Ezra Klein Show,‚Äù which transitioned to video late last year. Coates was there to discuss a column that Klein had written about the assassination of the right-wing activist Charlie Kirk, in which Klein argued that Kirk had practiced politics ‚Äúthe right way.‚Äù Coates had published a rejoinder in Vanity Fair, pointing out that Kirk had ‚Äúreveled in open bigotry.‚Äù Their t√™te-√†-t√™te on Klein‚Äôs show, staged at a bare-bones studio table, added a human component to their battle of ideas. Coates looked visibly taken aback as he discussed Klein‚Äôs choice not to call out Kirk‚Äôs hateful ideology, and supportive viewers turned his skeptical face into a kind of reaction meme. Klein‚Äôs more placid affect, meanwhile, did little to absolve him of critiques of political abstraction and whitewashing. In the video-podcast era, those best able to project their authenticity through the small screen win‚Äîand it‚Äôs not always the people who film themselves the most often.
As the internet‚Äôs content-distribution channels become overwhelmingly cluttered with spam, misinformation, and A.I.-generated slop and propaganda, video podcasts have the considerable advantage of serving as markers of reality, at least for now. Viewers are reassured to see a voice coming directly out of a face, and a conversation documented for a stretch of time that would seem difficult to fake. ChatGPT can blandly spit out infinite facts, but individual eloquence is still in limited supply. What‚Äôs unclear is whether the video-podcast format can sustain the explosion of entrants as more talking heads in journalism, politics, entertainment, and tech jockey for attention in a digital landscape already beset by chronic distraction. In the past few months alone, we‚Äôve seen the arrival of new video podcasts from Emily Sundberg‚Äôs buzzy New York City newsletter ‚ÄúFeed Me‚Äù; the sports agent Rich Paul and the ESPN commentator Max Kellerman, under the umbrella of The Ringer; the comedian Ilana Glazer; and PBS. (The New Yorker is not immune from the trend: it now films some episodes of The New Yorker Radio Hour.) Least expected, perhaps, was the launch of ‚ÄúThe Liz Truss Show,‚Äù hosted by the former British Prime Minister, on YouTube. Truss‚Äôs time in office lasted all of six weeks, but, with a clip-on microphone and a wonkish backdrop, perhaps she can gin up a new kind of following, one videotaped chat at a time. ‚ô¶
news.summary: Whether you‚Äôre a pundit, a politician, or an A-list comedian, the best media strategy these days is a D.I.Y. stage set and a microphone.
news.author: Kyle Chayka

news.title: This High-Profile Race Shows Exactly What Has Changed In The Democratic Party
news.text:
WASHINGTON ‚Äî There‚Äôs plenty of reason to be skeptical of Rep. Jasmine Crockett‚Äôs chances in Texas‚Äô U.S. Senate race. While Crockett‚Äôs television hits and podcast interviews delight liberals, she‚Äôs only ever won in safely Democratic seats. Her preferred strategy of focusing on increasing base voter turnout has little track record of success. Republicans are openly ecstatic about her decision. 

But if Democratic elected officials share this skepticism, they‚Äôre unwilling to say it out loud. They‚Äôre also not willing to fully back her campaign or endorse her over her primary opponent, state Rep. James Talarico. 

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs entirely possible that she can put together a good campaign,‚Äù said Sen. Ruben Gallego (D-Ariz.).

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs an outstanding person and an important voice in her state,‚Äù added Sen. Raphael Warnock (D-Ga.).

‚ÄúI‚Äôm obviously focused on the House, not the Senate,‚Äù said House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries (D-N.Y.), declining to speak on the ambitions of one of the most high-profile members of his caucus.

Uncertainty about the utility of Crockett‚Äôs bid extended even to Sen. Chris Murphy (D-Conn.), one of the members of the so-called ‚ÄúFight Club‚Äù group of progressive senators pushing for a more aggressive approach to combating Donald Trump.

‚ÄúThere are some places where the primaries are good, and there are places where they can be a pain in the ass,‚Äù Murphy told HuffPost. ‚ÄúA primary can, you know, ultimately cause a lot of new people to register and cause a lot of new people to get involved.‚Äù

The wishy-washiness greeting Crockett is reflective of the party‚Äôs uncertainty about how to navigate the anti-Trump, anti-establishment energy coursing through the party, which closely mirrors the GOP‚Äôs crack-up in the first half of the 2010s. Democrats are hoping to mirror the incredibly strong midterm election performances Republicans had in those years.

But they are hoping to avoid the downsides the GOP experienced in those years: Primary voters repeatedly picking weak candidates who handed winnable elections to the opposition. The consensus among party operatives is Crockett is the Democratic equivalent of Christine O‚ÄôDonnell or Richard Mourdock, a candidate whose fighting spirit animates the party‚Äôs base but whose rhetoric ‚Äî like Crockett saying conservatives are ‚Äúinherently violent‚Äù or suggesting Latino Trump supporters have a ‚Äúslave mentality‚Äù ‚Äî repels swing voters. 

‚ÄúThis feels like a Democratic tea party moment,‚Äù said Adam Carlson, founder of the Democratic polling firm Zenith Research. ‚ÄúDemocratic primary voters are tired of having candidates dictated to them, and they‚Äôre saying, ‚ÄòStop telling us who‚Äôs electable. We‚Äôre going to vote for who we like the best.‚Äô‚Äù 

The party‚Äôs establishment has long succeeded at closely managing primaries. Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.), known as a ferocious recruiter, was also adept at subtly and not-so-subtly discouraging candidacies, helping the party avoid contentious primaries in Florida and Kansas in recent years. 

And voters largely went along with party leaders‚Äô wishes. In the first midterm under Trump, wins by insurgent progressives like Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.) were the exception rather than the rule, with voters ‚Äî especially in swing states and districts ‚Äî backing moderate candidates seen as safe choices to win. That trend largely continued through the 2020, 2022 and 2024 elections. 

Democrats in those elections often benefited from anti-Trump energy, and clear cases of the party picking the wrong nominee were few, far between and often limited to lower-stakes races for the U.S. House. But some party operatives fear they could be far more common this cycle.

Sen. John Fetterman (D-Pa.) indirectly compared Crockett to Aftyn Behn, the Tennessee state legislator whose liberal stances and controversial social media posts some Democrats blamed for blowing the party‚Äôs shot at a deep-red House seat earlier this month.

‚ÄúI do know that Texas is red, and then I do know that you have to bring some people over to the other side,‚Äù Fetterman told HuffPost. ‚ÄúAnd now, what happened in Tennessee? You know, we had that total train wreck on our side, and that could have been actually really, truly competitive if it was like a more reasonable kind of a candidate.‚Äù

Crockett‚Äôs entrance into the race seemingly forced former Rep. Colin Allred, potentially a much stronger candidate, to challenge Rep. Julie Johnson for a safe Democratic House seat instead. Allred ran 6 percentage points ahead of former Vice President Kamala Harris in the state when he challenged Sen. Ted Cruz last cycle.

Allred‚Äôs team portrayed his decision, which leaves Talarico as Crockett‚Äôs only competition in the primary, as a selfless one that would give the party‚Äôs nominee a 13-week head start in the general election by avoiding a runoff, which is a near certainty in the GOP primary between incumbent Sen. John Cornyn, Attorney General Ken Paxton and Rep. Wesley Hunt. (Texas requires runoffs in primaries if no candidate breaks 50% of the vote.)

But as the likelihood of Crockett running for Senate became clear in recent weeks, Democrats in the state couldn‚Äôt find anyone willing to discourage her. Senate Democrats do not yet view Texas, an ultra-expensive state that might only be competitive if Cornyn loses to the deeply conservative and ethically challenged Paxton, as an essential part of their pathway to the majority. 

Even if they had, Crockett, to put it lightly, does not seem to be the type swayed by the pleas of party elders. 

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs weird that people believe that I could win the races that I won and I‚Äôm just like out here willy-nilly,‚Äù she told CNN last week before officially announcing her decision. ‚ÄúBut OK. I am very self-aware, right?‚Äù

With Allred out of the race, it is now a showdown between Crockett and Talarico, widely seen as another rising star in the party and someone who has amassed a $5 million war chest since entering the race this summer, according to the Federal Election Commission filings from October. (Crockett has roughly $4.6 million in her account.) 

Crockett‚Äôs unelectability, in the eyes of most Democratic operatives, comes down to both her insistence on turning out Democratic base voters at the expense of persuasion and her tendency to actively insult Trump voters.

‚ÄúThere just aren‚Äôt enough Democrats to win using a base-heavy strategy in Texas,‚Äù Carlson said.

The other concern Democrats have about Crockett is, as one strategist put it, her ‚Äúrobust self-image.‚Äù Her campaign announcement did not include any mention of policies or voter concerns; it was a video of herself with audio of Trump insulting her. Early on in her kickoff speech, Crockett said she was running because ‚Äúwhat we need is for me to have a bigger voice.‚Äù 

Crockett‚Äôs campaign did not respond to an email requesting comment. During an appearance on CNN on Monday night, Crockett went further than previously in suggesting she would reach out to some Trump voters. 

‚ÄúWe are going to be able to get people that potentially have voted for Trump even though I, obviously, am one of his loudest opponents because at the end of the day, they vote for who they believe is fighting for them,‚Äù she told host Laura Coates.

But she reiterated her top priority would be turning out otherwise apathetic voters, a strategy even many other progressives have backed away from. ‚ÄúOur goal is to make sure that we can engage people that historically have not been talked to because there are so many people that get ignored, specifically in the state of Texas,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúListen, the state of Texas is 61% people of color. We have a lot of good folk that we can talk to.‚Äù

One Democrat working for a House campaign in Texas‚Äô heavily Latino Rio Grande Valley ‚Äî an area that has swung sharply to Republicans over the past decade ‚Äî noted Crockett‚Äôs announcement video included no mention of the high cost of living, a message the party has used to successfully win back Latino voters elsewhere in elections this year.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs simply not the message these voters are looking for,‚Äù said the operative, who requested anonymity to speak frankly because his candidate is neutral in the Senate primary. ‚ÄúPeople here are worried about a downballot bloodbath.‚Äù 

While Crockett has an advantage in name identification and starts out in the lead, Democrats watching the race say she also has uniquely high unfavorable ratings, even among members of her own party. Talarico allies hope a closer look at Crockett‚Äôs record ‚Äî including her past support for Israel, her ties to the cryptocurrency industry and her acceptance of corporate political action committee money ‚Äî rather than just her TV appearances, will convince the party‚Äôs voters Talarico gives them the best chance of winning statewide in Texas for the first time in 30 years. 

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre building a movement in Texas ‚Äî fueled by record-breaking grassroots fundraising and 10,000 volunteers who are putting in the work to defeat the billionaire mega-donors and puppet politicians who have taken over our state,‚Äù Talarico said in a statement after Crockett‚Äôs entrance into the race. ‚ÄúOur movement is rooted in unity over division ‚Äî so we welcome Congresswoman Crockett into this race.‚Äù
news.author: Igor Bobic,Kevin Robillard

news.title: Mike Johnson Finally Reveals GOP‚Äôs Health Care Plan‚Äîand It‚Äôs Rough
news.text:
‚ÄúLemme tell ya. Black people love Trump. I got the biggest vote,‚Äù he said, before raising his voice even louder in the microphone. ‚ÄúI got the biggest vote with Black people, they know a scam better than anybody! They know what it is to be scammed.‚Äù

It‚Äôs difficult to parse whether he‚Äôs attributing Black people‚Äôs knowledge of scams to antiquated racist tropes or making an allusion to the slavery and history of economic discrimination they have endured in America (perhaps the latter is much too generous). Either way, the jury is still very much out on just how much Black people like him.

After Trump made notable gains with the Black vote in 2024, any momentum that he may have had with them since defeating Vice President Kamala Harris last year seem to have evaporated.
news.summary:
House Speaker Mike Johnson just unveiled Republicans‚Äô plan to address spiking health care costs‚Äîand it‚Äôs a disaster. 

As Affordable Care Act tax credits are set to expire in just a few weeks, sending health care costs surging for more than 20 million Americans, Republican leadership presented several bullet points Wednesday on how they plan to lower premiums and give Americans better health options. 

Instead of subsidizing premiums for those on Affordable Care Act plans, Republicans proposed introducing Health Savings Accounts, Association Health Plans, and Choice Accounts. 

Americans who don‚Äôt get insurance through their employer would be given cash directly into an account, which would reportedly be paired with a high-deductible health plan, meaning higher insurance premiums would be replaced by higher out-of-pocket costs. 

Currently, Obamacare enrollees never see the funds from their tax credits, which instead are sent directly to insurers. President Donald Trump has suggested that consumers would rath

news.title: Trump will be on the ballot as much as possible in 2026. It didn‚Äôt work in Miami
news.text:
Donald Trump wants to help Republicans by putting himself front and center in next year‚Äôs midterm elections.

He tried it in the race for Miami mayor and it didn‚Äôt work.

The candidate Trump endorsed in the race, Republican Emilio Gonz√°lez, lost by nearly 20 points to Democrat Eileen Higgins Tuesday in a city Kamala Harris barely won last year, and became the city‚Äôs first Democratic mayor in three decades.

‚ÄúFor the president to weigh in on a local race like this and to lose is embarrassing,‚Äù anti-Trump Republican political consultant Mike Madrid said.

The surge of support in Miami for a Democratic candidate could be a harbinger of what‚Äôs to come next year when voters decide which party will control Congress ‚Äî and Trump‚Äôs involvement didn‚Äôt stem the tide of Republican losses that began in New Jersey and Virginia last month.

After those losses, Trump‚Äôs midterm strategy is to get more involved. He plans to endorse Republicans in races that presidents don‚Äôt normally weigh in on, according to his chief of staff Susie Wiles.

‚ÄúTypically in the midterms, it‚Äôs not about who‚Äôs sitting in the White House. You localize the election and you keep the federal officials out of it. We‚Äôre actually going to turn that on its head and put him on the ballot,‚Äù Wiles said in an interview released Monday by an online show called The Mom View.

Wiles, a longtime Florida Republican political consultant and lobbyist, pointed to last month‚Äôs Republican losses elsewhere in the country as evidence of ‚Äúwhat happens when he‚Äôs not on the ballot and not active.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs going to campaign like it‚Äôs 2024 again,‚Äù she added. ‚ÄúHe doesn‚Äôt help everybody, but for those he does, he‚Äôs a difference maker.‚Äù

On Tuesday night, however, Trump put himself on the Miami ballot and it didn‚Äôt make a clear difference: Higgins garnered 59% of the vote Tuesday to Gonz√°lez‚Äô 41%.

For Democrats, Tuesday‚Äôs results are exactly the type of win against a Trump-endorsed candidate they hope to replicate during the regular election cycle next year.

‚ÄúMayor-elect Eileen Higgins‚Äô win is a testament to what Democrats can accomplish when we organize and compete everywhere, including in Miami,‚Äù DNC chair Ken Martin said Tuesday night.

The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee pointed to it as a warning sign to Rep. Maria Elvira Salazar, who has recently been openly critical of Trump and called his latest immigration crackdown ‚Äúun-American.‚Äù

‚ÄúTonight‚Äôs victory proves yet again that Democrats are on offense in some of the most competitive political terrain in the country as we continue to expand the battlefield,‚Äù Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee spokesperson Madison Andrus echoed.

Longtime Florida Democratic consultant Steve Schale said Higgins‚Äô win is clearly not an indicator ‚ÄúFlorida is back in play‚Äù for Democrats, but he said the significance of Democrats winning a mayoral seat in Miami can‚Äôt be written off as simply an off-year result.

‚ÄúHer winning is a bigger deal than what happened in New York City,‚Äù he said, pointing to Zohran Mamdani‚Äôs win over Trump-endorsed Andrew Cuomo.

He also took a long-term view, harkening back to Florida mayoral wins two decades ago that proved to be an early sign of Florida becoming more competitive ahead of Barack Obama winning Florida in 2008.

‚ÄúFlorida looked really uncompetitive after the 2004 presidential election. We had a governor‚Äôs race decided by a dozen points. We had a presidential race that wasn‚Äôt close,‚Äù Schale said. ‚ÄúThe first sign that showed that Florida was potentially reverting back to the mean of being a little bit more competitive was a number of mayor‚Äôs races in 2005.‚Äù

For Democrats, building back a beleaguered party against a Republican party that holds every statewide office and holds a supermajority in the state Legislature is a massive lift that one December election is unlikely to change. But Florida Democratic Party Chair Nikki Fried hopes the win will start to convince national investors not to write Florida off as permanently red.

‚ÄúHow can the rest of the nation not wake up and see that we are making progress?‚Äù Fried told the Herald ahead of Election Day.

Republicans minimize the loss

Some Florida Republicans insisted that Higgins‚Äô win wasn‚Äôt a referendum on Trump and that instead, Trump‚Äôs presence in the race wasn‚Äôt emphasized enough. Trump‚Äôs endorsements were limited to social media posts, not a visit or robocalls, and came after Higgins placed well ahead of Gonz√°lez and 12 other candidates during the Nov. 4 general election.

‚ÄúI actually think [Wiles] has the right formula. Where it failed this time for Miami was that we didn‚Äôt push Trump enough,‚Äù Miami Republican Executive Committeewoman Angie Wong told the Herald Tuesday night. ‚ÄúI think the messaging was lost in Miami that we had a Trump-endorsed candidate.‚Äù

Gonz√°lez downplayed the partisan framing of the race ‚Äî a contest that had both campaigns sending mailers highlighting Trump‚Äôs endorsement of Gonz√°lez. One Florida Democratic Party mailer told voters to ‚Äúsend a clear message: Trump‚Äôs endorsement will be rejected in Miami.‚Äù

‚ÄúI wanted this to be a municipal race,‚Äù he said at his Election Night party in downtown Miami about 30 minutes before the results came in. ‚ÄúI wanted this to be about Miami.‚Äù

The Republican ‚Äì who called Higgins a ‚Äúsoft socialist‚Äù on the campaign trail ‚Äì insisted he was also courting Democrats throughout the campaign, and wouldn‚Äôt have minded some high-profile Democratic support, too. He was up against a 8,800 Democratic voter registration advantage in the race.

‚ÄúHell, I‚Äôll take Biden‚Äôs endorsement,‚Äù he said of the former president, the one candidate to beat Trump in an election. ‚ÄúWhen you get endorsed by a president, that means a lot.‚Äù

Gonz√°lez said he thought the president‚Äôs backing galvanized Republicans during the runoff and boosted his party‚Äôs motivation to vote. While Democrats cast about 1,200 fewer ballots in the runoff than they did in the first-round election last month, Republicans cast about 1,200 more than they did in November. ‚ÄúMore Republicans turned up,‚Äù Gonz√°lez said.

Both candidates emphasized local issues throughout their campaign, with a focus on rejecting corruption and bringing integrity and honesty to city hall.

Leading up to election day, Republicans lowered expectations for a win. Despite Trump‚Äôs endorsement in the race, Florida GOP chair Evan Power called Miami a ‚ÄúKamala district.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre fighting there because we‚Äôre fighting everywhere,‚Äù he said Monday.

Democrats have typically won the city in major elections and lead in voter registration, even though they haven‚Äôt held the mayoral seat since the late 1990s. Manny Diaz, mayor from 2001 to 2009, went on years later to be chairman of the Florida Democratic Party, but renounced his affiliation with the party prior to his first election.

Miami Dade GOP Chairman Kevin Cooper cautioned people from making too much of the results.

‚ÄúThe unfortunate result of one campaign,‚Äù he said, ‚Äúis not the unfortunate result of an agenda or of a party.‚Äù

Miami Herald staff writers Doug Hanks and Tess Riski contributed to this report.

This story was originally published December 10, 2025 at 12:32 PM.
news.author: Claire Heddles

news.title: Minnesota University Accused of Harboring Illegal Alien Predator
news.text:
Jesus Saucedo-Portillo seems like a guy you wouldn't want hanging around your neighborhood or your kids' college campus. He's in the country illegally, for starters, but it gets worse than that; Saucedo-Portillo is a registered sex offender, with at least one conviction for driving while impaired. So, not exactly an Eagle Scout.

But when Immigration & Customs Enforcement (ICE) tried to pick Saucedo-Portillo up on the campus of Augsburg University, a small private college in Minneapolis, where he was unaccountably taking classes despite being in the country illegally, a school administrator and - get this - campus security tried to stop them.

That's right. A school administrator and the campus security apparatus tried to stop the legal arrest of an illegal alien and convicted criminal.

On Monday night, DHS, responding to a local news report, said on X that ICE agents arrested Jesus Saucedo-Portillo, a criminal illegal alien and registered sex offender with a prior conviction for driving while impaired.That arrest was hindered when a school administrator teamed up with campus security and attempted to prevent ICE agents from doing their job.Saucedo-Portillo is an undergraduate student at Augsburg University in Minneapolis.

Not anymore, he isn't. Is it belaboring the obvious to note that this guy could have actually posed a danger to the students of Augsburg University?

"Our officers told the school Administrator and campus security that ICE had a warrant for the illegal alien's arrest. The school Administrator told ICE officers they were violating university policies," the statement said. "Our officers informed them that federal law supersedes any University policy and that if campus security would not stop blocking the law enforcement vehicle from exiting, they would be obstructing justice."Despite the warning, the administrator refused to back down and ordered campus security to block the ICE vehicle, according to DHS."Our officers followed their training to use the minimum amount of force necessary to clear the area and successfully arrested this criminal illegal alien," the statement finished.In an interview with Minnesota Public Radio, Augsburg President Paul Pribbenow corroborated that Saucedo-Portillo is a student and claimed that the arrest was "illegal" and that ICE did not have a warrant.

The officers were correct. ICE is under no obligation to give any consideration to the university's policies. Augsburg University can pass all the policies they like, they can define pi as 3 and insist that the stars are the lights of the heavens shining through holes in the celestial spheres for all they like, and that won't change the facts on the ground, that being that federal law that enables ICE to do their jobs supersedes anything they decree. The arrest wasn't illegal, just because this turbocharged son of a vacuum-cleaner salesman says so, in total disregard for the safety and well-being of his students.

Read More: ICE Strikes Back: Dangerous Illegals Nabbed in New Minneapolis Sweep

You can't even parody these people. They are already beyond that.

Here's the thing: If this same, exact action were taken during, say, the Obama administration, it's a near-certainty that Paul Pribbenow wouldn't have offered a peep in reply. And the Obama administration was, to be fair, no slouch in kicking illegals out of our country. So, where were the leftist protests then? Where were the useful idiots setting fire to cars and waving Mexican flags? 

This isn't about the illegal aliens. It's not about immigration law. It's about Trump Derangement Syndrome, pure and simple. If Kamala Harris had won the 2024 election, and we should be grateful every waking moment that she didn't, and if she had implemented this exact crackdown on illegal immigration, the left would have not only ignored it - they almost certainly would have celebrated it. Augsburg University would have handed this guy over on a silver platter.

Augsburg officials did not return multiple requests for comment.

You don't say.

Editor‚Äôs Note: Thanks to President Trump, illegal immigration into our great country has virtually stopped. Despite the radical left's lies, new legislation wasn't needed to secure our border, just a new president.

news.title: WTF? Embracing profanity is one thing both political parties seem to agree on
news.text:
By STEVEN SLOAN, Associated Press

WASHINGTON (AP) ‚Äî As he shook President Barack Obama‚Äôs hand and pulled him in for what he thought was a private aside, Vice President Joe Biden delivered an explicit message: ‚ÄúThis is a big f‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî deal.‚Äù The remark, overheard on live microphones at a 2010 ceremony for the Affordable Care Act, caused a sensation because open profanity from a national leader was unusual at the time.

More than 15 years later, vulgarity is now in vogue.

During a political rally Tuesday night in Pennsylvania that was intended to focus on tackling inflation, President Donald Trump used profanity at least four times. At one point, he even admitted to disparaging Haiti and African nations as ‚Äú shithole countries ‚Äù during a private 2018 meeting, a comment he denied at the time. And before a bank of cameras during a lengthy Cabinet meeting last week, the Republican president referred to alleged drug smugglers as ‚Äúsons of b‚Äî‚Äî-s.‚Äù

While the Biden incident was accidental, the frequency, sharpness and public nature of Trump‚Äôs comments are intentional. They build on his project to combat what he sees as pervasive political correctness. Leaders in both parties are seemingly in a race now to the verbal gutter.

Vice President JD Vance called a podcast host a ‚Äúdips‚Äît‚Äù in September. In Thanksgiving remarks before troops, Vance joked that anyone who said they liked turkey was ‚Äúfull of s‚Äî-.‚Äù After one National Guard member was killed in a shooting in Washington last month and a second was critically injured, top Trump aide Steven Cheung told a reporter on social media to ‚Äúshut the f‚Äî- up‚Äù when she wrote that the deployment of troops in the nation‚Äôs capital was ‚Äúfor political show.‚Äù

Among Democrats, former Vice President Kamala Harris earned a roar of approval from her audience in September when she condemned the Trump administration by saying ‚Äúthese mother‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî- are crazy.‚Äù After Trump called for the execution of several Democratic members of Congress last month, Sen. Chris Murphy, D-Conn., said it was time for people with influence to ‚Äúpick a f‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî side.‚Äù Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer of New York said the administration cannot ‚Äúf‚Äî- around‚Äù with the release of the Jeffrey Epstein files. Democratic Rep. Jasmine Crockett, who on Monday announced her Senate campaign in Texas, did not hold back earlier this year when asked what she would tell Elon Musk if given the chance: ‚ÄúF‚Äî- off.‚Äù

The volley of vulgarities underscore an ever-coarsening political environment that often plays out on social media or other digital platforms where the posts or video clips that evoke the strongest emotions are rewarded with the most engagement.

‚ÄúIf you want to be angry at someone, be angry at the social media companies,‚Äù Utah Gov. Spencer Cox, a Republican, said Tuesday night at Washington National Cathedral, where he spoke at an event focused on political civility. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not a fair fight. They‚Äôve hijacked our brains. They understand these dopamine hits. Outrage sells.‚Äù

Cox, whose national profile rose after calling for civility in the wake of conservative activist Charlie Kirk‚Äôs assassination in his state, approved an overhaul of social media laws meant to protect children. A federal judge has temporarily blocked the state law.

Tough political talk is nothing new

Tough talk is nothing new in politics, but leaders long avoided flaunting it.

Recordings from Democrat Lyndon B. Johnson‚Äôs administration, for instance, revealed a crude, profane side of his personality that was largely kept private. Republican Richard Nixon bemoaned the fact that the foul language he used in the Oval Office was captured on tape. ‚ÄúSince neither I nor most other Presidents had ever used profanity in public, millions were shocked,‚Äù Nixon wrote in his book ‚ÄúIn the Arena.‚Äù

‚ÄúPoliticians have always sworn, just behind closed doors,‚Äù said Benjamin Bergen, a professor at the University of California-San Diego‚Äôs Department of Cognitive Science and the author of ‚ÄúWhat the F: What swearing reveals about our language, our brains, and ourselves.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe big change is in the past 10 years or so, it‚Äôs been much more public.‚Äù

As both parties prepare for the 2026 midterm elections and the 2028 presidential campaign, the question is whether this language will become increasingly mainstream. Republicans who simply try to imitate Trump‚Äôs brash style do not always succeed with voters. Democrats who turn to vulgarities risk appearing inauthentic if their words feel forced.

For some, it is just a distraction.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not necessary,‚Äù said GOP Rep. Don Bacon of Nebraska, who is retiring next year after winning five elections in one of the most competitive House districts. ‚ÄúIf that‚Äôs what it takes to get your point across, you‚Äôre not a good communicator.‚Äù

There are risks of overusing profanity

There also is a risk that if such language becomes overused, its utility as a way to shock and connect with audiences could be dulled. Comedian Jerry Seinfeld has talked about this problem, noting that he used swear words in his early routines but dropped them as his career progressed because he felt profanity yielded only cheap laughs.

‚ÄúI felt like well I just got a laugh because I said f‚Äî- in there,‚Äù he said in a 2020 interview on the WTF podcast with fellow comedian Marc Maron. ‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt find the gold.‚Äù

White House spokesperson Liz Huston said Trump ‚Äúdoesn‚Äôt care about being politically correct, he cares about Making America Great Again. The American people love how authentic, transparent, and effective the President is.‚Äù

But for Trump, the words that have generated the most controversy are often less centered in traditional profanity than slurs that can be interpreted as hurtful. The final weeks of his 2016 campaign were rocked when a tape emerged of him discussing grabbing women by their genitals, language he minimized as ‚Äúlocker room talk.‚Äù His ‚Äúshithole‚Äù remark in 2018 was widely condemned as racist.

More recently, Trump called a female journalist ‚Äúpiggy,‚Äù comments that his press secretary, Karoline Leavitt, defended as evidence of a president who is ‚Äúvery frank and honest.‚Äù Trump‚Äôs use of a slur about disabled people prompted an Indiana Republican whose child has Down syndrome to come out in opposition to the president‚Äôs push to redraw the state‚Äôs congressional districts.

On rare occasions, politicians express contrition for their choice of words. In an interview with The Atlantic published last week, Gov. Josh Shapiro, D-Pa., dismissed Harris‚Äô depiction of him in her book about last year‚Äôs presidential campaign by saying she was ‚Äútrying to sell books and cover her a‚Äî.‚Äù

He seemed to catch himself quickly.

‚ÄúI shouldn‚Äôt say ‚Äòcover her a‚Äî,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI think that‚Äôs not appropriate.‚Äù
news.summary: Leaders in both parties are openly using vulgarities.
news.author: Associated Press

news.title: WTF? Embracing profanity is one thing both political parties seem to agree on

By STEVEN SLOAN, Associated Press

WASHINGTON (AP) ‚Äî As he shook President Barack Obama‚Äôs hand and pulled him in for what he thought was a private aside, Vice President Joe Biden delivered an explicit message: ‚ÄúThis is a big f‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî deal.‚Äù The remark, overheard on live microphones at a 2010 ceremony for the Affordable Care Act, caused a sensation because open profanity from a national leader was unusual at the time.

More than 15 years later, vulgarity is now in vogue.

During a political rally Tuesday night in Pennsylvania that was intended to focus on tackling inflation, President Donald Trump used profanity at least four times. At one point, he even admitted to disparaging Haiti and African nations as ‚Äú shithole countries ‚Äù during a private 2018 meeting, a comment he denied at the time. And before a bank of cameras during a lengthy Cabinet meeting last week, the Republican president referred to alleged drug smugglers as ‚Äúsons of b‚Äî‚Äî-s.‚Äù

news.title: Trump Threatens to Fire His Treasury Secretary Over ‚Ä¶ Immigration?
news.text:
‚ÄúLemme tell ya. Black people love Trump. I got the biggest vote,‚Äù he said, before raising his voice even louder in the microphone. ‚ÄúI got the biggest vote with Black people, they know a scam better than anybody! They know what it is to be scammed.‚Äù

It‚Äôs difficult to parse whether he‚Äôs attributing Black people‚Äôs knowledge of scams to antiquated racist tropes or making an allusion to the slavery and history of economic discrimination they have endured in America (perhaps the latter is much too generous). Either way, the jury is still very much out on just how much Black people like him.

After Trump made notable gains with the Black vote in 2024, any momentum that he may have had with them since defeating Vice President Kamala Harris last year seem to have evaporated.
news.summary:

As part of a longer rant Tuesday about how much better the country is now than it was under former President Joe Biden, Trump once again turned his ire on Somali immigrants. 

‚ÄúBiden and the radical-left Democrats turned Pennsylvania into a dumping ground for hundreds of thousands of migrants from the most dysfunctional places on earth, like Somalia, and gave them billions and billions of your taxpayer dollars. But we didn‚Äôt really give it. It was stolen. And those people should go to jail! Jail!‚Äù the president yelled.

‚ÄúAnd if they don‚Äôt go to jail? Scott Bessent is toast,‚Äù Trump said, laughing. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs toast.‚Äù

Trump: Those people should go to jail! Jail! And if they don't go to jail, Scott Bessent is toast. He's toast. pic.twitter.com/dxaJnPMTsr
